text: how is it that a nose detect scents and
and get to sort of you know the idea of
vanilla versus jasmine so the magic of
the sense of smell is that it's it's a
it's a chemical sense you have to if you
if you if you if you ask someone to
smell something it will typically close
their eyes and you take a breath in and
so then you're you're bringing chemicals
into your nose and you have this big
array of proteins that are able to bind
to those smell molecules in different
ways and so you could imagine if you
have if you have 400 options and each of
them can bind to a combination of
different scents the coding potential
the number of different smells that you
can encode with the system is huge as
vast as sort of uncountable which is
really convenient because we don't know
what sense we might encounter in the
future so the human nose is prepared for
virtually for virtually any sense and so
if you get on a plane and travel to
another part of the world you don't have
to learn to tech those things you can
encounter a completely unfamiliar sense
because you're endowed with this this
huge set of of chemical detectors and
there's some overlap in the code so
there's some overlap in vanilla so you
may activate some of the same receptors
with the scent of vanilla and the scent
of jasmine but it can also get really
complicated they can start canceling
each other out so when you start mixing
things together which is what perfumers
do things can become very unpredictable
so there's been good experiments showing
that if I train each of you to smell
jasmine or vanilla or something like
wintergreen you can learn to distinguish
though as once I start mixing them
together people are completely stumped
it's like my Jo Malone lime mandarin
orange lotion thank God she didn't go
beyond three because once once once you
go beyond three components people are
completely stumped because the 400
receptors start interacting and and
something it will be like a plus B will
produce Z so completely different
percept emerges which is why perfumery
ends up being so empirical and so
artistic because you can't you can you
can predict what colors you guys have
all mixed colors together you can you
you can predict what you'll get if you
mix two colors you actually can't
predict what will happen if you mix two
smells
